Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: The grandmother learns that a family member is dealing with a significant personal crisis.
Expectation2: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation2: A medical supply delivery must reach a hospital department on schedule to ensure patient care
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was double-checking the address on a box of urgent medical supplies. The hospital’s name was bold on the label, and I knew the delivery had to be on time—lives could depend on it. But the message on my phone made my hands tremble: my daughter was in tears, telling me that my grandson had been rushed to the ER after a bad fall. As a grandparent, I felt the pull to drop everything, call her back, and be the comforting voice she needed. My family expected me to be present, to check in, to offer support in moments like this. But as a delivery person, I was expected to keep my route, to get this package to the hospital department without delay. I could feel the weight of both roles pressing on me, each demanding my full attention, each impossible to ignore. My heart ached for my family, but my hands gripped the steering wheel, torn between the road ahead and the call I so desperately wanted to make.
